questions.text: As the medical superintendent of a hospital, you wish to optimise the utilization of health services. What bed turnover interval should you aim for?
questions.solution:
For optimum utilization of health services in a hospital, bed turnover interval must always be slightly positive.

Bed turnover interval is defined as the time interval where a hospital bed is left unoccupied following a patient’s discharge till the next patient occupies it after admission.

questions.text: You are tasked with holding a public service announcement about the benefits of getting vaccinated to a small town of farmers. You want to deliver some statistical data to encourage vaccination. Which of the following is the best way to do so?
questions.solution:
Pictograms are a popular method of presenting data among the laity and to those who cannot understand orthodox charts. 

Small pictures or symbols are used to present the data. Fractions of the picture can be used to represent numbers smaller than the value of a whole symbol. These can be easily understood by laymen and have a greater impact than complex graphs or charts.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about composting?

choices.text: Bangalore method is an aerobic process
Mechanical composting uses a controlled environment
Nightsoil can also be disposed with composting
Compost has few or no disease-causing pathogens

questions.solution:
The Bangalore method of composting is an anaerobic process.

Composting is a method of combined disposal of refuse and nightsoil. In this process, organic matter is broken down into compost. It has manure value and few or no disease-causing pathogens.

Bangalore method is an anaerobic method and is also called hot fermentation process. Trenches with a depth of not more than 90cm are used for this. This is done by spreading a layer of refuse (15 cm thick) at the bottom of the trench and nightsoil (5cm thick) is added next. Layers of refuse and nightsoil are added alternatively till the heap rises to 30cm above ground level. The heap is then covered with excavated earth. At the end of 4 – 6 months, decomposition will be completed.

Mechanical composting is an aerobic process. In this method, compost is manufactured on a large scale by processing raw materials and turning out a finished product. The refuse is first cleared of salvageable materials. It is then pulverised to reduce the size of particles to less than 2 inches. The pulverised refuse is then mixed with sewage, sludge or nightsoil in a rotating machine and incubated.

questions.text: Which of the following is a synthetic pyrethroid insecticide?
questions.solution:
Permethrin is a synthetic pyrethroid. Pyrethroids are synthetic insecticides, which are derived from naturally occurring pyrethrins. Pyrethroids modify the sodium channels in neuronal membranes and thereby disrupt the electrical signalling in the nervous system. 

Permethrin is effective in killing or repelling insects and is often used in products like insect repellent sprays, creams, and treated clothing for personal protection against insect bites.

Other options:

  • Propoxur is not a synthetic pyrethroid insecticide. It is a carbamate insecticide used for pest control.
  • Parathion is not a pyrethroid insecticide either. It is an organophosphorus insecticide, which works differently from pyrethroids.
  • Pyrolan is not a commonly known insecticide and is not a synthetic pyrethroid.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about De Quervain’s thyroiditis except______

choices.text: Treatment of choice is supportive and NSAIDs
Characterized by painful and enlarged thyroid
Both thyrotoxic and hypothyroid phases can be observed

questions.solution:
De Quervain’s thyroiditis is not autoimmune in origin. It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections.

Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been clinically implicated in this condition. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years and women are generally affected three times more often than men.

Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever.

It has three distinct phases: The thyrotoxic phase followed by the hypothyroid phase and the recovery phase.

It is treated with large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids and/or beta-blockers to relieve the observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid phase is prolonged - levothyroxine can be used.

questions.text: Central pontine myelinolysis is caused by  ______
questions.solution:
Rapid correction of hyponatremia may result in central pontine myelinolysis.

Central pontine myelinolysis is an osmotic demyelination syndrome, wherein rapid correction of hyponatremia results in water being driven out of the cell which has adapted to a chronic state of hypotonicity leading to damage to the myelin sheath of these cells.

When a person with severe hyponatremia receives treatment to rapidly increase their blood sodium levels, it can disrupt the osmotic balance in the brain. The brain cells have adapted to the lower sodium levels, and rapid correction can lead to the movement of water out of these cells, causing them to shrink and damage the myelin sheath, which is the protective covering of nerve fibers in the central pontine region of the brain. This demyelination can result in the characteristic neurological symptoms of CPM.

The condition is often seen in individuals with severe, chronic hyponatremia, such as in alcoholics or people with certain medical conditions.

It is characterized by the acute onset of quadriparesis, ataxia, and abnormal extraocular movements.

questions.text: Alcoholic liver disease is suspected in a patient presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting. Which among the following makes the diagnosis of alcoholic liver disease unlikely?
questions.solution:
An AST: ALT <2 makes the diagnosis of alcoholic liver disease unlikely. 

In alcoholic liver disease(ALD), usually the AST: ALT is > 2:1. This is due to:

  • Deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate in alcoholics. Pyridoxal 5'-phosphate is a cofactor for the enzymatic activity of ALT. Therefore, ALT levels fail to rise.

In ALD,

Option B: Prothrombin time (PT) is prolonged due to the decreased synthetic function of the liver.

Option C: Platelet counts are often reduced early in the disease, which is reflective of portal hypertension with hypersplenism.

Option D: Serum total bilirubin can be normal or elevated with advanced disease.

questions.text: A 70-year-old chronic smoker presents with a history of intermittent crampy lower abdominal pain and episodic diarrhea that has progressively worsened over the past 2 weeks. Examination revealed tenderness in the right iliac fossa and a positive guaiac test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this given case scenario is Crohn's disease.

This patient's history is suggestive of ileocolitis which commonly presents as recurrent episodes of right lower quadrant pain and diarrhea. The most common site of inflammation in Crohn's disease is the terminal ileum. 

The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis.  

Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, smoking is seen to have a protective effect in ulcerative colitis.

Other options-

Option B- Diverticulitis occurs in the sigmoid colon, therefore they have left-sided signs and symptoms. 

Option D- Irritable bowel syndrome is not characterized by bowel inflammation and is a diagnosis by exclusion.

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent epigastric pain with a burning sensation for the past 2 years. The pain usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food. He also says that he sometimes wakes up at night because of severe pain. The most probable cause for his symptoms is:
questions.solution:
Epigastric pain with burning sensation that usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food suggestive of duodenal ulcer.

The following patterns of pain are usually seen in peptic ulcer disease:

Duodenal Ulcer- Pain occurs 1.5 to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Pain may awaken the patient from sleep.

Gastric Ulcer- Pain/discomfort may be precipitated by food. Nausea and weight loss are common.

Perforated ulcer- The bed of the ulcer tunnels through the entire thickness of the gastric wall and opens into the peritoneum. This presents with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and leads to peritonitis. Radiography shows gas under the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female cook presents with a 1-year history of dyspnea, episodic cough, wheeze, shortness of breath, and chest tightness.  What is the best way to diagnose bronchial asthma in this patient?
questions.solution:
The best way to diagnose bronchial asthma is by the demonstration of reversible obstruction of the airways.

Wheeze, dyspnoea, and reduced FEV1 values are nonspecific indicators of airway obstruction and are seen in any of the obstructive pathologies (i.e. asthma, COPD, and bronchiectasis). Therefore, they do not independently diagnose asthma.

Whereas, the administration of an inhaled beta 2 agonist can differentiate between Asthma and COPD as follows:

  • ≥12% (≥200ml) increase in the FEV1 demonstrates the reversibility of airway obstruction which is diagnostic of bronchial asthma.
  • <12% or no increase in FEV1 demonstrates the irreversibility component of airway obstruction indicating COPD.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
Inspiratory coarse crackles are not a feature of interstitial lung disease. Auscultating a patient with ILD will reveal bilateral basal inspiratory fine crackles, also called velcro crackles.

ILD refers to the remodelling of interstitial space, the region between the epithelium and endothelium. Patients with interstitial lung disease usually present with a non-productive cough and breathlessness on exertion. 

Clubbing may be seen on examination, especially in advanced cases. DLCO (diffusion capacity of lung) is decreased. Fever and wheezing are usually not seen in patients of ILD.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with diarrhoea, confusion, high-grade fever, and bilateral pneumonitis. Which pathogenic agent is suspected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of confusion, high-grade fever, and bilateral pneumonitis with associated diarrhea is highly suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by Legionella.

Legionnaire’s disease mostly presents as atypical pneumonia. Risk factors include advanced age, immunocompromised patients, chronic smoking, and long-standing lung disease. Diarrhea (watery rather than bloody) is reported in 25–50% of cases. The most common neurologic abnormalities are confusion or changes in mental status.

Urine for legionella antigen is the preferred test. Drugs of choice are azithromycin and respiratory quinolones (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin).

questions.text: A 43-year-old obese man presents with loud chronic snoring and gasping episodes during sleep along with excessive daytime sleepiness. He is diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea. Which of the following would be the ideal therapy for his symptoms?

choices.text: Implantable neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS). The ideal therapy is continuous positive airway pressure therapy (CPAP).

Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is the most common surgery done in OSAHS but it is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.

Supplemental oxygenation can improve oxygen saturation but there is little evidence that it improves OSAHS symptoms.

Unilateral neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve through a surgically implanted device is a recently tested therapy for OSAHS. It can be used as an alternative in selected patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.

questions.text: A woman with HIV was brought into the emergency ward after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. There is no history of fever, night sweats, and weight loss. MRI  was done and the ​image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This HIV patient with seizures and MRI showing a solitary rim-enhancing lesion in the left posterior frontal lobe most likely has cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis:

  • It is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL.
  • It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

Diagnosis:

MRI: Usually multiple lesions in multiple locations, however, in some cases a single lesion may be present. These lesions are associated with inflammation and central necrosis and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Surrounding edema is usually present.

Treatment: Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 

Prophylaxis: Primary prophylaxis with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given to patients with low CD4+ T cell count. The same regimen also offers primary protection against P. jirovecii. 

Other conditions with single or multiple enhancing mass lesions in the HIV-infected patient include primary CNS lymphoma (usually solitary, solid and subependymal lesion) and, less commonly, TB or fungal or bacterial abscesses.

Cryptococcus neoformans is the most common cause of meningitis in HIV patients. It does not cause ring-enhancing lesions

Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumour of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Patients usually present with headaches, ataxia, and signs of brainstem involvement

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is encephalitis caused when JC polyomavirus infects the oligodendrocytes and leads to demyelination. It usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals. The patients develop focal and progressive neurological symptoms. MRI would show multifocal, asymmetric periventricular and subcortical involvement.

questions.text: A child presents with megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin C, vitamin B12, and folic acid, but responsive to uridine. What do you suspect?
questions.solution:
Orotic aciduria is to be suspected in this child.

Megaloblastic anemia that is responsive to uridine is consistent with orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism in children. A defect in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway results in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine.

Supplementation of vitamin B12, folate, and vitamin C rules out the more common nutritional causes of megaloblastic anemia. To rule out the other options:

Pernicious anemia responds to treatment with vitamin B12.

Thiamine deficiency and anemia due to liver disease do not respond to uridine.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with Cotrimoxazole.  He developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain and dark urine. The blood picture is given below. The most likely diagnosis is  ________.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above case scenario is Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

The clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following the administration of cotrimoxazole. A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria. 

The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells" or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen.

Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole which triggers a hemolytic reaction in persons with G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient was detected to have a Hb-18 g/dl, hematocrit-54%, and an elevated erythropoietin level. Which of the following is the least likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Polycythemia vera is the least likely diagnosis as erythropoietin levels are normal or reduced in it.

Polycythemia means an increase in the number of red blood cells in the body. It is classified as

  • Primary polycythemia- occurs due to the mutations in the hematopoietic stem cells. Since the defect is in the hematopoietic stem cells, an increase in the white blood cells and platelets also can be seen. The erythropoietin levels are normal or decreased. Eg. Polycythemia vera
  • Secondary polycythemia- occurs due to an increase in the level of erythropoietin. This stimulates the production of RBCs. Since the hematopoietic stem cells are normal, the platelet and WBCs are normal. Important causes are:
    • Hypoxia due to chronic lung disease, high altitude, carbon monoxide poisoning
    • Autonomous production of erythropoietin in renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, etc.
  • Relative (spurious) polycythemia- Here the red cell count or the hemoglobin count appears elevated due to a decrease in the plasma volume. It is commonly seen in dehydration.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in patients with type 1 renal tubular acidosis?

choices.text: Urinary pH is < 5.5 after acid loading

questions.solution:
Urinary pH will be > 5.5 after acid loading in RTA type 1.

In this condition, there is a defect in H+ secretion by the distal tubules. Hence, there is a failure of urine acidification and NH₄⁺ excretion. In the acid loading test, acidosis is induced by the administration of NH4Cl (releases H+). In normal individuals, this results in increased excretion of H+, leading to acidic urine (pH < 5.5). However, this fails to occur in RTA type 1.

Impaired secretion of H+ leads to potassium wasting and hypokalemia (via the H+/K+ATPase antiporter). The resulting metabolic acidosis causes bone demineralization and resorption.

questions.text: Which intravenous fluid is preferred for the hydration of patients with pre-renal acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Isotonic crystalloids like 0.9% NaCl are preferred for the correction of hypovolemia in pre-renal AKI.

Management of AKI:

1. AKI care bundle:

  • Nephrotoxic drugs should be avoided and the dosage of other drugs must be adjusted according to kidney function
  • Creatinine levels and urine output must be closely monitored

2. Hemodynamic management:

  • If hypovolemic - fluid replenishment using isotonic crystalloids (normal saline)
  • If euvolemic - fluid intake = urine output + additional ~500 mL 
  • If hypervolemic - diuretics are administered. If the response is unsatisfactory, dialysis is required.

3. Management of complications:  

  • Pulmonary edema - Treated with diuretics, non-invasive ventilation, and dialysis if refractory
  • Metabolic acidosis - Treated when pH <7.2 with oral or IV sodium bicarbonate
  • Hyperkalemia - Treated by restriction of dietary potassium, administration of sodium polystyrene sulfonate, insulin, glucose, inhaled β-agonist, and calcium gluconate

Options A and B: Hydroxyethyl starch solutions and dextrans increase the risk of severe AKI and are contraindicated.

Option D: Ringer's lactate is preferred only when a large volume of fluids is required.

questions.text: A resident is evaluating a patient, who presented with acute onset of chest pain and dyspnea, for pulmonary embolism. Which of the following imaging test should be performed to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CT pulmonary angiography should be performed as it is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE).

Option A: Most patients with acute PE have normal echocardiograms. However, echocardiography is a very useful diagnostic tool for detecting conditions that may mimic PE, such as acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

Option C: Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, used mostly for patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast or in whom the CT results are inconclusive.

Option D: MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE. It is used when neither CT angiography nor ventilation-perfusion scan can be done.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with heart failure with an ejection fraction < 40%. What is the treatment of choice in this patient after the euvolemic status has been achieved?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors + beta-blockers are the treatment of choice in patients with heart failure with an ejection fraction of <40% after euvolemic status is achieved using diuretics.

The first-line drugs used in congestive heart failure with reduced ejection fraction are ACE inhibitors + diuretics. Once the euvolemic status is achieved, ACE inhibitors + beta-blockers are the drugs of choice.

Beta-blockers that improve survival in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction are carvedilol, metoprolol, and bisoprolol.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presented with chest pain that was unrelated to physical exertion. ECG showed ST-segment elevation. Intracoronary acetylcholine provocation testing revealed a transient spasm of the right coronary artery. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario in which rest pain is associated with ST-segment elevation and transient coronary vasospasm is suggestive of Prinzmetal's angina. The drug of choice is a calcium channel blocker.

Prinzmetal variant angina (PVA) is a clinical syndrome in which chest pain occurs without the usual precipitating factors. It usually results from coronary vasoconstriction (vasospasm) and tends to involve the right coronary artery.

It is a supply ischemia and usually causes transmural ischemia (subendocardial in classic angina pectoris).

It often affects women under 50 years of age. It characteristically occurs in the early morning, awakening patients from sleep, and may be associated with arrhythmias or conduction defects.

The clinical diagnosis of PVA is made by the detection of transient ST-segment elevation with rest pain. Coronary angiography demonstrates transient coronary spasm which is the diagnostic hallmark of PVA.

Nitrates and calcium channel blockers both can be used in alleviating symptoms in Prinzmetal's angina. However due to the development of nitrate tolerance in some individuals, they are less preferred and calcium channel blockers such as verapamil, diltiazem are used as first-line agents.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with complaints of syncope. ECG is suggestive of LV hypertrophy. A doppler echocardiography revealed abnormal systolic anterior leaflet motion of the mitral valve. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Nitrates, such as nitroglycerin, can lead to vasodilation and may reduce preload. This reduction in preload can exacerbate the obstruction in the left ventricular outflow tract, worsening the symptoms in some patients with HOCM.

Smaller chamber size and increased contractility exacerbate the severity of obstruction. These include conditions of low preload, such as dehydration, and low afterload, such as arterial vasodilation.

Drugs that can lead to possible aggravation of outflow tract obstruction and thus contraindicated in HCM are:

  • Digoxin
  • Inotropes
  • Nitrates
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg- nifedipine, amlodipine)

Beta-blockers and verapamil are first-line agents in the treatment of HCM. Disopyramide and amiodarone are the preferred antiarrhythmic agents.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken immediately. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features:

  • Wide QRS complex- QRS ≥120 ms 
  • Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6.
  • M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) 

MI can have the following ECG changes:

  • ST-segment elevation- zone of injury
  • T wave depression
  • Deep Q waves- late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6)

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient comes to the emergency room with a history of severe retrosternal pain radiating to the jaw. The patient initially felt some uneasiness while eating lunch after which he experienced pain. His ECG is as shown. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior chest leads suggestive of myocardial infarction.

Features of MI on ECG:

  • ST-segment elevation: Zone of injury
  • T wave inversions
  • Deep Q waves: late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

Option A: Atrial flutter shows a sawtooth wave pattern. 

Option B: WPW syndrome shows delta waves.

Option D: Ventricular tachycardia has wide QRS complex and increased heart rate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with sudden onset speech difficulty, tremors, and difficulty in walking. He is noted to have a wide stepping gait. He is a known hypertensive but is not adherent to treatment. Where is the lesion most likely to be seen on neuroimaging?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of cerebellar ataxia, hence the lesion is most likely to be seen in the cerebellum. Cerebellar ataxia can be caused due to an acute vascular event such as infarction or hemorrhage.

Wide stepping gait, a broad-based unstable gait is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction. Few other notable gait abnormalities are:

  • Short stepped gait- parkinsonism
  • Scissoring gait- spasticity i.e. UMN lesion
  • High-stepped, slapping gait- posterior column or peripheral nerve disease
  • Waddling gait- proximal muscle weakness

A few of the cerebellar signs include:

  • Dysdiadokinesia / dysmetria
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Intention tremor
  • Speech - slurred or scanning
  • Hypotonia

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the OPD with complaints of frequent fainting and sudden falls while playing. She sometimes falls off while sitting in the classroom hitting her head to the desk. She regains consciousness immediately and resumes her activity, and has normal behavior after such episodes. The girl is otherwise healthy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history is most consistent with atonic seizures. Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural control and there is no postictal confusion.

Options A and D: Absence seizures usually present as blank stares or unresponsiveness for a few seconds. Postural control is not lost during absence seizures.

Option C: The girl regains consciousness immediately and has no associated complaints like sweating, fatigue, or tachycardia. She also resumes her activity after the episodes. Also, there is no precipitating factor that points towards syncope. Hence it is unlikely to be syncope.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman who was brought to the ER with hemiparesis was found to have a lacunar infarction. What causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Lacunar infarcts, also called small vessel stroke, refer to infarction following atherothrombotic or lipohyalinotic occlusion of small penetrating arteries in the brain. These penetrating arteries arise from the stem of the middle cerebral artery, circle of Willis, and basilar and vertebral arteries.

The principal risk factors are hypertension and old age.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common antecedent infectious cause of Guillain-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
Campylobacter jejuni is one of the most common risk factors for GBS.

Infections that may trigger GBS are:

  • Campylobacter jejuni 
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • Epstein Barr virus
  • Mycoplasma
  • Varicella zoster virus
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), dengue, or influenza, Zika, hepatitis

Less commonly vaccinations, surgical procedures, and trauma have been reported to trigger the development of GBS.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins will you prescribe for a patient on antitubercular therapy?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid (INH), which is a first-line anti-tuberculosis drug, inhibits pyridoxal phosphokinase, resulting in pyridoxine deficiency and neuropathy. Prophylactic administration of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) 10 mg/day can prevent neuropathy from developing. 

10 mg daily suffices for prophylaxis but patients with evidence of vitamin B6 deficiency may require up to 50 mg daily.

Current WHO guidelines recommend routine substitution of pyridoxine to patients who are at risk of peripheral neuropathy, e.g., malnutrition, chronic alcohol dependence, diabetics, HIV.

However, pyridoxine excess (acute intoxication or long-term use of large doses) is also found to cause peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: You observed the following finding in a patient in the OPD. Which among the following conditions is least likely to cause this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows digital clubbing. Among the given options, aortic dissection is least likely to cause digital clubbing.

Clubbing is a selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes due to the proliferation of connective tissue, particularly on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Interstitial lung diseases
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease (Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease)
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Neoplasms - esophagus, liver, bowel
    • Cirrhosis - juvenile and biliary
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Subacute bacterial endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous fistula
    • Patent ductus arteriosus with right to left shunt
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Grave’s disease (thyroid acropachy)
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)
  • Skin disease
    • Palmoplantar keratoderma
    • Fischer-Volavsek syndrome.
  • Malignancies
    • Thyroid cancer
    • Thymus cancer
    • Hodgkin disease
    • Disseminated chronic myeloid leukemia.

Note: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) does not cause clubbing. If clubbing is present in a patient with COPD, underlying lung cancer and bronchiectasis must be ruled out.

questions.text: An infant presents with copious bilious vomiting and abdominal distension on the 5th day of life. He had not passed meconium for the first 3 days after birth. An abdominal radiograph shows the presence of dilated bowel loops. What is the gold standard investigation for the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung’s disease.

A rectal biopsy 2 cm above the dentate line is the ideal area for a biopsy.

Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.

The initial investigation is a contrast enema. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone. The affected part shows the absence of ganglion cells and hypertrophy of nerve trunks in the rectal biopsy.

Other investigations for Hirschsprung’s disease include:

  • Water-soluble contrast enema - shows the presence of contracted aganglionic rectum, transition zone, and a dilated normally innervated colon.
  • Anorectal manometry - shows the failure of the relaxation of the internal anal sphincter.

 Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure, where endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum. The ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain that is relieved on loud belching. On examination, the patient had pallor. Chest radiography showed an intrathoracic gas bubble. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a hiatus hernia. Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.

Type 1 - Sliding hernia:

Gastroesophageal junction or cardia migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD. Most of the patients are asymptomatic. The treatment of choice in symptomatic patients is fundoplication.

Type 2 - Rolling hiatus hernia:

Gastroesophageal junction or cardia is normal but a portion of the stomach migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus hernia.

Clinical features:

  • Chest pain or fullness relieved on belching.
  • Dysphagia.
  • Longitudinal ulcers (Cameron’s ulcer) that bleed lead to anemia.

Surgical reduction of hernia and tightening of diaphragmatic crura is the best treatment modality even in asymptomatic patients to avoid life-threatening complications like volvulus.

Type 3 - Mixed hiatus hernia:

A combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia. Treatment is the same as rolling hiatus hernia.

Type 4 Hiatus hernia:

Other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Eg: Colon.

CT with oral contrast is the best method of diagnosis of hiatus hernia. It highlights gastric anatomy and also helps to identify other structures involved. Chest X-ray shows an intrathoracic gas bubble.

questions.text:
Which of the statements regarding opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI) are correct?
1. Hemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitides and, Streptococcus pneumoniae are the most common causative agents
2. Risk is greatest in patients who have undergone splenectomy for trauma
3. Risk is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy
4. Prophylactic vaccination should be done 2 weeks prior to elective splenectomy
5. No vaccination is needed in case of an emergency splenectomy
questions.solution:
The statements 1, 3 and 4 are correct regarding opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI). The risk of developing OPSI is greatest when splenectomy is done for haematological conditions than for post-trauma. 

Opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI) is a major complication following splenectomy due to septicemia, which may result from an infection of:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Neisseria meningitides
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Escherichia coli.

The risk of overwhelming sepsis is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy.

Hence, if an elective splenectomy is planned, consideration should be given to vaccinating against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) at least 2 weeks before elective surgery.

In case of emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the capsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: A 73-year-old diabetic man is brought to the emergency with an altered sensorium. He is dehydrated and his blood glucose is 550mg/dl. A hyperosmolar, hyperglycemic state is suspected. Which of the given formulae can correctly evaluate his serum osmolality?
questions.solution:
Calculated serum osmolality = 2 sodium + (glucose/18) + (BUN/2.8).

In the given clinical scenario, the patient with untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus has most likely developed a hyperosmolar, hyperglycemic state. His serum osmolality will be significantly raised.

The principal determinants of osmolality of serum are the concentrations of sodium, glucose and urea (blood urea nitrogen or BUN).

Osmolality is defined as a measure of the osmoles (Osm) of solute per kilogram of solvent (osmol/kg or Osm/kg). The osmolality of the intracellular and extracellular fluids is maintained between 290 and 310 mOsm in each compartment.

questions.text: Which among the following best describes sepsis?

choices.text: Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score  ≥ 1
Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score  ≥ 1
Suspected or documented infection with SIRS score ≥ 2

questions.solution:
Among the given options suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2 best describes sepsis.

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

Sepsis is defined as a “life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection.” It lies in the continuous spectrum between infection and septic shock.

There is no gold-standard method or investigation to diagnose sepsis with certainty. However, the risk of organ dysfunction (sepsis) in patients with suspected infection can be determined using the sequential (sepsis-related) organ failure assessment - SOFA score. This includes:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version of the SOFA score is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment - qSOFA score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

 

The Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) score is no longer recommended as it is not specific to infection.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presented with recurrent bilious vomiting. An X-ray erect abdomen is given below. What is the next best step in managing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with the radiograph showing the triple bubble sign implies a diagnosis of jejunal atresia. A contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other large bowel anomalies.

Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. 

  • Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia
  • Abdominal distension is more prominent with ileal atresia.

A small amount of pale meconium may be passed despite the atresia. 

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction. A contrast enema study can demonstrate a narrow calibre of colon and may also be useful to exclude multiple atresias, which may be present in 10% to 15% of cases.

In most cases of jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is done. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis.

questions.text: Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS) includes which of the following components?
questions.solution:
TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) includes :

  • Injury Severity Score (ISS)
  • Revised Trauma Score (RTS)
  • Age
  • Mechanism of injury (blunt/penetrating).

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 3 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score

questions.text: Which of the following structures will not be removed while performing radical mastectomy in patients with breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Supraclavicular lymph nodes are not removed in radical mastectomy.

In Halsted radical mastectomy, the following structures are removed:

  • All breast tissue and skin
  • Nipple-areolar complex
  • Pectoralis major and pectoralis minor muscles
  • Level I, II, and III axillary lymph nodes.

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

Breast conservative surgery is also known as segmental mastectomy, lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, wide local excision, and tylectomy.

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Subcutaneous mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast without overlying skin.
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Axillary lymph nodes (Levels I + II ± III)
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iversion) mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular lymph nodes
  • Super radical mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular + Mediastinal lymph nodes

questions.text: An infant with Edward's syndrome presents with the following radiological finding. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Mostly presents as vomiting within 1 week
Erythromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life can lead to this condition
Palpation of the pyloric olive is pathognomonic  for this condition

questions.solution:
The radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). It most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting between 2-8 weeks of age and is only rarely seen after 13 weeks.

Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk.

Risk factors for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

  • Turner syndrome
  • Edwards syndrome
  • Erythromycin or azithromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life either orally or via mother's milk.

Palpation of the olive-shaped mass in the epigastrium is considered pathognomonic. 

USG criteria for diagnosing hypertrophic pyloric stenosis - pyloric muscle thickness of >3-4 mm or a pyloric length >15-18 mm in the presence of functional gastric outlet obstruction is diagnostic.

questions.text: Which type of anal fistula is seen in this image?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the fistula traverses the internal sphincter and tracks down the space between the internal and external anal sphincters. Hence, it is an inter-sphincteric type of anal fistula. It is the most common anal fistula.

A fistula-in-ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. Patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain. Anal fistulas can be simplex or complex fistulas.

  1. Simple fistulas- include a single tract, subcutaneous tract, and those that involve less than 30% of the external sphincter. They are easier to treat, and have lower chances of recurrence. 
  2. Complex fistulas- include fistulas involving more than 30% of the external sphincter, with multiple tracts, recurrent fistulas, and those associated with other predisposing factors, such as Crohn disease and radiation treatment.

Fistulas can also be classified into high or low-lying fistulas, based on their location with respect to the puborectalis muscle.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presented with umbilical discharge. Abdomen examination was normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of embryonal umbilical anomalies such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step in the management of this case is the USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous, or of fistula.

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities:

  • Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which gets obliterated eventually.
  • The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct can lead to various abnormality depending on the part of a duct that is persistent.
    • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel’s diverticula.
    • Persistence of the distal end near umbilicus leads to umbilical polyp or sinus.
    • Persistence of distal end with mucus retention leads to cyst, which may be associated with the intestine or the umbilicus by means of a fibrous band.
    • Fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to enterocutaneous fistula.

questions.text:
All of the following are post-hepatic causes for portal hypertension, except_____
  1. Budd Chiari syndrome
  2. Splenomegaly
  3. Chronic right-sided cardiac congestion
  4. Sarcoidosis
  5. Primary biliary cholangitis
questions.solution:
Splenomegaly is a pre-hepatic cause of portal hypertension. Sarcoidosis and primary biliary cholangitis are presinusoidal intrahepatic causes of portal hypertension.

Portal hypertension occurs when the pressure in the portal vein increases due to either increased resistance to blood flow secondary to fibrosis, active vasoconstriction, or hyperdynamic systemic circulation.

Related Pearl: Portal hypertension-causes

questions.text: According to Strasberg’s classification of bile duct injuries, injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak is:
questions.solution:
Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg’s type C injury.

The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define bile duct injuries.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with recurrent attacks of dizziness and abdominal pain for 3 months. Fasting blood glucose level was 40 mg%, and insulin levels were elevated. CT abdomen showed a well-defined 1 cm lesion in the head of the pancreas. The treatment plan should be _______.
questions.solution:
Recurrent hypoglycemic symptoms (dizziness) and low blood glucose with elevated insulin is suggestive of insulinoma. Tumour enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.

Insulinomas of <2 cm in diameter without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. 

Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:

  • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
  • Tumors of size >2 cm
  • Tumors within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct

Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich meals, octreotide or diazoxide.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency with a painful scrotum. On examination, the patient is febrile and a Prehn’s sign is positive. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute epididymitis. 

A positive Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymis from testicular torsion. A Prehn’s sign is said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis. If it persists, it is likely to be testicular torsion.

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of acute epididymitis in young, sexually active males. In older men(>40yrs) with bladder outflow obstruction, epididymitis results from urinary infection, most commonly due to Escherichia coli.

Acute epididymitis is managed by antibiotics and scrotal support.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a Doyen’s mouth gag.

It is used to keep the mouth open for intraoral surgery when retraction of the tongue is not required or desirable. Mostly used for tongue surgery. It is applied on one side of the mouth on molar teeth.

Option A: Doyen’s retractor is used to retract abdominal wall in abdominal and pelvic surgeries to expose field of operation.

Option C: Doyen’s intestinal occlusion clamp is used to for resection and anastomosis of intestine in case of

  • Strangulated hernia
  • Accidental injuries to the gut
  • Intestinal growths
  • Gastric/intestinal bypass surgeries

Option D: Joll’s thyroid retractor is a self retaining retractor used in thyroid surgeries to retract skin.

questions.text: Which of the following is increased in burns?
questions.solution:
Burns are associated with massive release of inflammatory mediators which produce increased capillary permeability, vasodilation and edema locally and in distant organs.

Cellular and humoral immunity are decreased in burns (increased risk of infection).

Changes in various systems in burns:

CVS

  • Massive edema
  • Decreased venous return
  • Decreased cardiac output

Renal

  • Low volume concentrated urine
  • Decreased urinary sodium
  • Myoglobinuria
  • Renal ischemia
  • Acute tubular necrosis
  • Acute renal failure

GI

  • Reflex Ileus
  • GI Ulcers (Curling’s Ulcer)

Endocrine and Metabolism

  • Increased glucagon, cortisol
  • Protein catabolism
  • Ureagenesis
  • Lipolysis
  • Increased gluconeogenesis

Hematological

  • Anaemia

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding Warthin tumor?

choices.text: It is seen in older white men

The tumor has no malignant potential.

questions.solution:
The Warthin tumor or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum is the second most common, benign parotid tumor. It usually presents as a unilateral tumor and occurs most often in the elderly and in the Caucasian race.

They are usually seen in the lower poles of the parotid and are associated with smoking.

Because of the high mitochondrial content in oncocytes, the oncocyte-rich Warthin tumor or oncocytoma incorporate technetium-99m and appear as hot spots on radionuclide scans.

It has no malignant potential.

 Note: 

The most common benign tumor of the parotid gland is a pleomorphic adenoma. The second most common benign tumor is Warthin's tumor.

Both pleomorphic adenoma and warthin's tumor commonly present as unilateral tumors. A bilateral presentation is usually rare.

However in rare cases, if there is a bilateral benign salivary tumor, the tumor is most likely to be a Warthin's tumor. Which means, warthin's tumor presents commonly as unilateral, rarely as bilateral. However, the incidence of these rare bilateral cases of warthin's tumor is more than incidence of the rare bilateral cases of plemorphic adenoma making warthin's tumor the most common benign tumor with bilateral development.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of jaundice with clay-colored stools and pruritis. After a detailed radiological and pathological investigations, a 2 cm adenocarcinoma is found at the head of the pancreas. There is no spread to the adjacent structures. What is the preferred surgical management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The preferred surgical management in this patient is pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy (PPPD), also known as Longmire–Traverso procedure. This procedure involves the removal of the duodenum and the pancreatic head and the distal part of the bile duct.

The original pancreatoduodenectomy, as proposed by Whipple, included resection of the gastric antrum. Preserving the antrum and the pylorus is thought to result in a better physiological outcome, with no difference in survival or recurrence rates. Currently, the pylorus is removed in cases when:

  • entire duodenum has to be removed (e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)),
  • tumor encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by PPPD

For tumors of the body and tail, distal pancreatectomy is the preferred surgical management.

Other options:

Option A: Whipple's procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when the entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), tumor encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach or a clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy.

Option C: Radical pancreaticoduodenectomy involves removing the head of the pancreas, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder, and part of the bile duct. It is primarily performed to treat pancreatic cancer and other tumors in the pancreatic head region, though it may also be used for chronic pancreatitis in some cases.

Option D: Cholecystojejunostomy is a surgical bypass procedure that creates a connection between the gallbladder and jejunum. It is done for unresectable pancreatic head tumors causing biliary obstruction, distal common bile duct obstruction and when hepaticojejunostomy is not feasible.

questions.text: A patient presented with retrosternal chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia. Manometry was done, which showed simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg). The probable diagnosis is_______.
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture and manometric findings are characteristic of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm - It is a poorly understood hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women.  Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles.

Investigations :

A barium swallow shows corkscrew esophagus. 

However, manometry is the gold standard test for diagnosis.

  • On classic manometry - simultaneous, multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds) are suggestive of DES (as given in the question).
  • On high-resolution manometry, a DCI (Distal contractile Integral) >450 mmHg is suggestive of DES. This is in accordance with the latest Chicago classification.

Treatment: Calcium-channel antagonists, vasodilators, and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects. Surgical treatment includes extended/long oesophageal myotomy, up to the aortic arch, if required. The surgical treatment of DES is more successful in improving dysphagia than chest pain.

The older terms "diffuse esophageal spasm" and "jackhammer (nutcracker ) esophagus" have been replaced in the Chicago classification by Distal esophageal spasm and Hypercontractile esophagus respectively. 

Related Pearl: Manometric findings in oesophageal disorders

Manometric Findings in Nutcracker Esophagus

  • Peristaltic esophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal
  • Amplitude > 180 mmHg and duration > 7seconds.
  • Normal peristaltic sequence

Manometric Findings in Diffuse Esophageal Spasm

  • Simultaneous, multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 sec)
  • These erratic contractions occur after more than 20% of wet swallows.
  • Intermittent normal peristalsis

Manometric Findings in Hypertensive Lower Esophageal Sphincter-

  • Elevated LES pressure > 26mmHg and normal relaxation of LES
  • The esophageal body may be hyper-peristaltic or normal.

Manometric findings in Achalasia Cardia

  • Incomplete LES relaxation
  • Aperistalsis in the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure ≥26 mmHg
  • Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to gastric baseline

Manometric findings in ineffective esophageal motility disorders

  • Decreased or absent amplitude of esophageal peristalsis (<30 mmHg)
  • Increased number of non-transmitted contractions

questions.text: An obstetrician performs the following procedure for labor induction in a patient. Which of the following is false about the reflex elicited here?

choices.text: Occurs due to pressure at the external os of cervix

Artificial rupture of membranes initiates this reflex
It is an example of positive feedback mechanism

questions.solution:
Stripping of membranes is being depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex. It is also known as the fetal ejection reflex and is seen due to the pressure at the internal os of the cervix.

Other options:

  • It is associated with an increase in blood levels of a prostaglandin F2α metabolite, also known as dinoprost. This is released due to mechanical stretching of the internal os. This enhances the uterine activity and causes release of more prostaglandins. It is an example of a positive feedback mechanism.
  • The Ferguson reflex can be initiated by various means, including artificial rupture of the amniotic membranes (amniotomy). When the amniotic sac is ruptured, it can lead to cervical stretching and stimulate the reflex, which, in turn, can result in uterine contractions.
  • The Ferguson reflex is indeed an example of a positive feedback mechanism. In positive feedback, the response to a stimulus amplifies the stimulus rather than counteracting it. In the case of the Ferguson reflex, the initial stretching of the cervix leads to uterine contractions, which, in turn, lead to further cervical stretching and stronger contractions, ultimately culminating in childbirth. This is a classic example of a positive feedback loop.

It usually occurs following vigorous curettage, repeated childbirth or in conditions with an excess of estrogen. Adenomyosis is more common in multiparous women aged 40 years and above. Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical assessment. A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined with curettage is the initial step in the management because of menorrhagia. Total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localised excision and levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger patients.

questions.text: A young woman suspected to have genital tuberculosis underwent an endometrial biopsy. She received a report confirming her diagnosis within a few hours. Which of the following diagnostic methods was most likely used here?
questions.solution:
As the report was received so fast, nucleic acid amplification technique (NAAT) was the likely method used as it can detect mycobacteria within a few hours. It also detects if the bacteria are resistant to rifampicin. 

Diode based fluorescent microscopy (LED FM) is a highly sensitive and specific method to diagnose tuberculosis. However, it requires 2-8 weeks to yield results and hence does not help in early diagnosis.

The BACTEC MGIT 960 is a fully automated, non-radiometric system used to diagnose TB. It uses the fluorescence of an oxygen sensor to detect the growth of mycobacteria in culture. It takes 13-14 days to give results.

The BACTEC 460 TB is a semiautomated, radiometric system where a radio-active carbon-labelled substrate such as palmitic acid or formic acid is used as a marker for detecting bacterial growth. It takes 14-15 days to detect mycobacteria in culture.

Other methods that can be used to diagnose genital TB are:

  • Semen culture can be done for vulvovaginal tuberculosis. It takes a longer duration with unsatisfactory results as compared to the other methods.
  • Gas chromatography involves direct demonstration of compounds characteristic of mycobacteria. It is 90% sensitive and provides a rapid diagnosis. However, it is expensive and not commonly done.

questions.text: A woman with AUB-E, who was unresponsive to medical management, underwent a hysteroscopic ablation. Which of the following is false about this procedure?
questions.solution:
Fertility is not preserved with ablative procedures, because the endometrium and superficial myometrium are destroyed.

In ablative procedures, the uterus is preserved, and hysterectomy is avoided. The endometrium along with 2-3mm of superficial myometrium is destroyed.

Various methods of endometrial ablation include:

  • Hysteroscopic endometrial ablation
  • Transcervical endometrial resection (TCRE) - now replaced by bipolar electrode called Versapoint
  • Radiofrequency induced thermal ablation (RITEA)
  • Microwave ablation
  • NovaSure - impedance-controlled endometrial ablation
  • Bilateral uterine artery embolization
  • Uterine tamponade

questions.text: The critical obstetric conjugate for trial of labor is ______.
questions.solution:
The clinically important obstetric conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis.

Normally, this measures 10 cm or more, but unfortunately, it cannot be measured directly by the examiner's fingers. For clinical purposes, the obstetrical conjugate is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate, which is determined by measuring the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory.

The red line marked 4 is the obstetric conjugate. The red line marked 5 is the pelvic outlet.

questions.text: A 32 year old female nearing her due date has been admitted following regular contractions. The resident doctor did an examination and told the intern that the head is at +1 station. Where is the exact position of head?

choices.text: High up in the false pelvis

questions.solution:
The station is just below the ischial spine.

The station of the head is in relation to ischial spines as spines are the most prominent bony projections felt on internal examination.

The level of ischial spines is halfway between the pelvic inlet and outlet. This level is known as station zero (0).

The levels above and below the spines are divided into fifths to represent centimeters. The station is said to be “O” if the presenting part is at the level of the spines. The station is stated in minus figures if it is above the spines (–1 cm, –2 cm, –3 cm, –4 cm, and –5 cm) and in plus figures, if it is below the spines (+1 cm, +2 cm, +3 cm, +4 cm, and +5 cm).

questions.text: A G2P1 female with 5 months of gestation comes to the OPD with complaints of swelling of both feet. On examination, her BP is 130/90 mmHg and she has bilateral pedal edema. What is the appropriate treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Bed rest is the appropriate treatment for women having edema in pregnancy.

The cause of physiological edema is due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressing on the common iliac veins.

Features of the physiological edema:

  • Slight degree (ankle edema)
  • Usually confined to one leg, more on the right
  • Unassociated with any other features of preeclampsia or proteinuria
  • Disappears on rest alone
  • Other pathologies of cardiac, renal and hematological are absent.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for female with atrophic vaginitis with complains of itching?
questions.solution:
Atrophic vaginitis is treated with topical estrogen vaginal cream.

Use of 1 g of conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally each day for 1 to 2 weeks generally provides relief. Systemic estrogen therapy should be considered to prevent recurrence of this disorder.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. And she is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain and on examination the right adnexal mass was palpable, non tender. On USG examination she has a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary. Which is the next step

choices.text: Reassure and advise regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualise the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.solution:
Doing a CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for Post-menopausal Ovarian cyst.

Initial steps in management include the following:

  • Estimate CA – 125 level
  • USG
  • Calculating Risk of Malignancy index
    • RMI = U x  M  x  Ca-125
    • U – Ultrasound score
    • M – Menopausal status
    • Ca 125 – Serum levels

Option B - CT scan is not recommended in initial evaluation.

Option C - Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size > 5 cm or RMI > 200.

questions.text: Which of the following is the endocrinological change of PCOD?
questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true regarding the endocrinological feature of PCOD.

Endocrine dysfunction includes the following: 

  • Insulin resistance 
  • impaired glucose tolerance and Type 2 diabetes mellitus 
  • Dyslipidemia: Increased LDL and triglyceride levels, elevated total cholesterol levels: High-density lipoprotein (HDL) ratios
  • Risk of endometrial cancer increased three-folds 
  • Infertility/subfertility 

Note: Mild elevations in testosterone levels are consistent with the diagnosis of PCOS. However, values > 200 ng/dL may suggest an ovarian tumour and warrant pelvic sonography.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: Red degeneration of fibroid was diagnosed in a pregnant woman who presented with an acute abdomen. How will you treat this patient___

questions.text: You would classify a baby as a very low birth weight baby if the weight of the baby is found to be less than _____ kg.
questions.solution:
A very low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <1.5 Kg. They are often premature (<37 weeks of gestation).

A low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <2.5 Kg.

An extremely low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <1 kg.

questions.text: A lady with wrong dates and a corrected gestational age of 43 weeks presents with labor pains. The CTG suggests placental insufficiency, and she is taken up for emergency LSCS. Which of the following physical signs is unlikely to be seen in this neonate?
questions.solution:
The physical sign of an infant born post-term (43 weeks) in association with presumed placental insufficiency is abundant hair (not scanty hair).

Infants born post-term in association with presumed placental insufficiency may have various physical signs, together termed as postmaturity syndrome (or dysmaturity syndrome).

These include:

  1. Desquamation, pale skin, and long nails.
  2. Loose skin around the thighs and buttocks.
  3. Meconium-stained nails, skin, vernix, and umbilical cord.
  4. Presence of placental membranes.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the clip. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clip depicts neonatal seizure of focal clonic type.

A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, and-

  • Maybe unifocal or multifocal
  • May occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body
  • May occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides
  • It cannot be suppressed by restraint

A focal tonic seizure is characterized by sustained posturing of single limbs, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, sustained eye deviation, cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.

Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.

Subtle seizures include transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, abnormal extremity movements (rowing, swimming, cycling, pedaling), fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies.

WHO recommendations:

  • Clinically apparent seizures in the neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief serial seizures.
  • If electroencephalography (EEG) is possible, all electrical seizures should also be treated, even in the absence of clinically apparent conditions.
  • In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia should be ruled out before anti-epileptic drug treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Head circumference should be measured within 24 hours after birth
Head circumference equals chest circumference at 1 year of age
A boys height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height
A girls height at 2 years is half of her adult height

questions.solution:
Head circumference should not be measured within 24 hours because the head is subjected to molding during delivery, which makes the measurements unreliable.

The maximum circumference of the head from the occipital protuberance to the supraorbital ridges on the forehead is recorded using the cross-tape method.

Age Head circumference
At birth 33 to 35cm
3 m 40 cm
6 m 43 cm
1 year 46 cm
2 years 48 cm
3 years 49 cm
4 years 50 cm
12 years 52 cm (adult size)
  • Head circumference increases by the following:
    • 2 cm/month in first 3 months
    • 1 cm/month in next 3 months
    • 0.5 cm/month in next 6 months

Head circumference is more than chest circumference by 2.5 cm at birth.

  • At birth: Head circumference > Chest circumference
  • At 9-12 months: Head circumference = Chest circumference
  • After 1 year: Head circumference < Chest circumference

Interesting fact!

A boy's height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height and a girl's height at 2 years is half of her adult height.

To roughly predict adult height, use the formula:

  • Adult height = height at 2.5 years for boys (or 2 years for girls) X 2

According to WHO growth charts, the height-for-age for most of the children lies between 70-90 cm during these periods. The double of it, i.e. 140-180 cm is the average height that most of us achieve as adults.

questions.text: You are taking a neonatal case for presentation during your postings. The mother tells you that the child is exclusively breastfed.  Which of the following is least likely to corroborate with this history of being exclusively breastfed?
questions.solution:
Exclusively breastfed infants are least likely to have evening colic. The incidence of diarrhoea, allergy to bovine milk, and atopic eczema are least reported in exclusively breastfed infants.

Option A: Vitamin K content of milk is low and may contribute to hemorrhagic disease of the newborn.

Option B: Breast milk contains inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase and enhances absorption of bilirubin from the gut. This leads to the development of breast milk jaundice. 

Option C: During the first few days, the breastfed infant has a black-green coloured stool. It changes to golden yellow by the end of the first week.

questions.text: You are an intern evaluating a 2-year-old girl child for malnutrition. The measurement with the WHO standard mid-upper-arm-circumference (MUAC) tape shows yellow. This reading would correspond to?
questions.solution:
The yellow colour on the new WHO standard mid-upper arm circumference of (MUAC) tape correlates to a MUAC of  11.5 to 12.5 cm.

MUAC tape cut-offs:

Colour Measurements Indication

 Yellow   11.5 to 12.5 cm Under-nourished
  Green   > 12.5 cm Normal

Mid-upper arm circumference is used in children between 6 to 60 months. It is measured between the acromion and olecranon process and is an age-independent parameter. 

WHO update:

A higher cut-off of 11.5 cm was recommended by the WHO. According to the new update, UNICEF started the supply of new MUAC tapes as described above.

Alternative methods for evaluating malnutrition:

Bangle Test - It has an internal diameter of 4 cms. Normally, it should not cross the elbow.

QUAC stick test - It is given by the formula - Mid-upper arm circumference/ Height of child

Skinfold thickness: It is an age-independent parameter. Routinely, we measure the triceps skinfold thickness. It is measured with the help of Harpenden calliper.

  • Normal: 10 mm
  • Severe malnutrition: < 6 mm

 What is the trinucleotide repeat mutation seen in the report?

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy presented with lethargy, failure to thrive, and developmental delay. On investigation, he had elevated levels of homocysteine in blood and homocystinuria. As the child grows, which of the following features is least likely to develop?
questions.solution:
The above findings support a diagnosis of homocystinuria. Short stature is not a manifestation of homocystinuria.

  • Ectopia lentis - downward and inward subluxation (inferonasal).
  • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders
  • Thromboembolic episodes like stroke and MI
