questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy?

choices.text: Myoclonic seizures frequently occur in morning.

questions.solution:
In juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, EEG characteristically shows 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges.

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome):

  • It is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults ( 12-18 years).
  • They are benign generalized myoclonic seizures with a good prognosis.
  • Typically, it starts in early adolescence (12-18 years), with 1 or more of the following manifestations:
    • Myoclonic jerks in the morning (“shock-like” contraction of a muscle, that is often repeated), generalized tonic–clonic or clonic seizures upon awakening; and juvenile absences.
    • Sleep deprivation, alcohol (in older patients), and photic stimulation provoke seizures.
    • The EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges.
  • The drug of choice for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is valproate. Lamotrigine is also useful.

questions.text: Laron syndrome is caused by _________.

choices.text: Deficiency of insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1)
Mutation in growth hormone- releasing hormone receptor

questions.solution:
Laron syndrome/dwarfism is caused by end-organ resistance to growth hormone due to the mutation of the growth hormone receptor.

Here, growth hormones are produced, but not able to act on the target tissues as growth hormone receptors are not responding to growth hormones in the target tissues. So, the resting and stimulated growth hormone levels are high and insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels are low.

It is an autosomal-recessive disorder with clinical features that are the same as those seen in pituitary dwarfism.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby presented with a history of constipation. Clinical examination reveals jaundice and hypotonia. His picture is provided below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the above picture, the child shows a protuberant abdomen, umbilical hernia, macroglossia, and edematous facies. Also, the infant has jaundice, constipation, and hypotonia, which suggests a diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism.

Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia: early sign
  • Constipation: usually does not respond to treatment
  • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular: slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory: macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Hematological: macrocytic anemia refractory to treatment with haematinics
  • Nervous system: hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness, and somnolence.

The clinical description and ultrasound finding of normal kidneys point to a diagnosis of hemolytic uremic syndrome.

questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress and drooling of saliva. Nasogastric tube cannot be passed to the stomach. There is history of maternal polyhydramnios. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of esophageal atresia with or without TEF.  In the setting of early-onset respiratory distress, the inability to pass a nasogastric or orogastric tube in the newborn suggests EA.

Features:

  • Esophageal atresia (EA) is the most common congenital anomaly of the esophagus. It is often associated with single umbilical artery.
  • >90% of babies with EA have an associated tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).
  • In the most common form of EA, the upper esophagus ends in a blind pouch and the TEF is connected to the distal esophagus.

CXR of pure EA can manifest as an airless scaphoid abdomen.

CXR showing a coiled feeding tube in the esophageal pouch and an air-distended stomach, indicating the presence of a coexisting TEF.

Other options:

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia:

Presents with respiratory distress in the neonatal period, scaphoid abdomen and bowel sounds which are present in the chest wall.
The tip of NG tube will be in the stomach in the thoracic cavity.
CXR shows: shows a stomach, nasogastric tube, and small bowel contents in the thoracic cavity, consistent with a CDH.

Acute Gastric Volvulus presents with classic symptoms (Borchardt triad) which include:

  • Unproductive retching (here patient presents with drooling NOT retching)
  • Localised epigastric distension
  • Inability to pass NG tube

questions.text: All of the following are the features of Kawasaki disease except:
questions.solution:
Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease.

Kawasaki disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome and is commonly seen in children between 3 months to 5 years of age.

Diagnosis of typical Kawasaki disease is made by fever for 5 or more days along with four of the symptoms listed below:

  • Bilateral conjunctival congestion (non purulent conjunctivitis)
  • Oral changes: erythematous, cracked lips and strawberry tongue
  • Non-suppurative cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Polymorphous rash
  • Changes in extremities: erythema and edema, desquamation of palms and soles.

questions.text: A person presents with the deformity shown in the picture and is unable to move the thumb away from the rest of the hand. Which of the following nerve is injured?
questions.solution:
The above picture shows ape thumb deformity. It results from median nerve palsy. Ape thumb deformity is inability to abduct the thumb due to paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle. The thumb remains parallel by the side of other fingers.

In the hand, the median nerve supplies muscles of the thenar eminence, mainly abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis and flexor pollicis brevis.

questions.text: Which type of non-union does the given radiograph signify?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows hypertrophic nonunion of the tibia.

Although the enlarged fracture ends suggest active osteogenesis, the gap is not bridged because of inadequate stability. Such non-unions have adequate vascularity and display abundant callus.

Based on increasing biologic potential for fracture healing, non-union can be of the following types:

  • Atrophic nonunion
  • Oligotrophic nonunion
  • Hypertrophic nonunion

Pseudoarthrosis has features of hypertrophic nonunion, but due to excessive and chronic motility, there is formation of a pseudo-capsule containing fluid similar to an actual synovial joint.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the OPD with a painless deformity. A radiograph of the child's legs is shown below. The most common cause of this deformity is ______.
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows bowing of legs in the child. The most common cause of this deformity is rickets.

In toddlers, bow leg or genu varum is one of the most common initial sign of rickets. In older children, genu valgum or coxa vara might be present.

The characterisric features of rickets include:

  • Delayed closure of the fontanelles
  • Frontal bossing
  • Craniotabes - soft skull bones
  • Rickety rosary - enlargement of the costochondral junction
  • Harrison sulcus 
  • Pigeon chest or pectus carinatum

questions.text: A young cricketer presented with severe pain and deformity of the shoulder following bowling practice. The AP-view radiograph of the affected shoulder is given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Bankart lesion may occur as a complication
Recurrence is associated with Hill-Sachs lesion
Radial nerve is most commonly injured
It can also be caused by a fall on the hand

questions.solution:
This radiograph shows anterior dislocation of the shoulder. The nerve commonly injured in anterior dislocation is the axillary nerve, not the radial nerve. 

The radiograph shows the disturbed articulation between the humeral head and glenoid fossa. The humeral head is seen below and medial to the glenoid socket. This suggests anterior dislocation of the shoulder joint. 

Common cause for anterior dislocation:

  • Young adults - athletic injuries
  • Elderly - falls (Option D)

Complications include:

  • Bankart lesion (Option A) is a tear in the anteroinferior part of the glenoid labrum caused by the head of the humerus during anterior dislocation. 
  • Hill-Sachs lesion is a compression fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head. It is caused by the pressure of the anterior glenoid rim on the humeral head in recurrent dislocations. (Option B)

questions.text: According to the Denis classification, which of the following is not included in the middle column of the spine?

choices.text: Posterior part of the vertebral body
Posterior part of the vertebral disc

questions.solution:
According to the Denis three-column theory, the posterior part of the pedicles is included in the posterior column of the spine, not in the middle column.

The 3 columns of the spine according to Denis classification are depicted in the image below.

The Denis classification is used to describe spinal injuries and classify them as stable or unstable. As per this system, any injury involving 2 columns or more is classified as unstable. Unstable injuries require surgical fixation.

The current AO/ASIF classification that replaced Denis classification reverts back to the previously prevalent two-column theory. It divides the spine as follows:

  • Anterior column: vertebral body and disc
  • Posterior column: pedicles, laminae, facets and posterior ligamentous complex

questions.text: The cystographic appearance shown below is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
Christmas tree bladder or pine cone bladder is a cystogram appearance which usually seen in severe neurogenic bladder with increased sphincter tone.

  • A pine cone bladder or Christmas tree bladder is a cystogram appearance in which the bladder is elongated and pointed with a thickened trabeculated wall.
  • It is typically seen in (detrusor sphincter dyssynergia) due to suprasacral lesions (above S2-S4) or epiconal lesions (in and around S2-S4).
  • Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination.
  • This finding is not pathognomonic of a neurogenic bladder. It can also be seen in patients with lesions anywhere along the sacral reflex arc. Occasionally, it is also seen in bladder neck obstruction of a non-neurogenic cause.

questions.text: An 18-month-child is brought to the pediatrician with the history of distension of abdomen and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and radiograph of the child is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As the child presents with mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly and cloudy cornea and given x-ray shows a J-shaped sella and a thickened calvaria, the most likely diagnosis is Hurler Syndrome.

Hurler syndrome is also known as MPS 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L Iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparin sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs (seen below)
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

 

Phenotypical features of Hurler's syndrome and Hunter's syndrome are quite similar; however, Hunter syndrome (deficiency of iduronate sulfatase enzyme) is generally less severe than Hurler syndrome and can be clinically differentiated by a lack of corneal clouding.

Increased choline reflects increased membrane synthesis and/or an increased number of cells, as seen in tumors. Choline is an important component of the cell membranes.

questions.text: Identify the mode in USG.
questions.solution:
The USG image represents M-mode used for echocardiography. Echo intensity is represented as brightness and trace is swept across the screen so that the x-axis represents time.

Modes in USG:

  1. A mode – amplitude mode is used in ophthalmology and orbital biometry 
  2. B mode/grayscale - used for all routine applications
  3. M mode – echocardiography (motion)

The advantage of USG is that there is no radiation and it is portable. It is the safest radiological investigation in pregnancy. It is the preferred investigation for:

  • Gall bladder pathology
  • Cysts
  • Fluid collection like ascites, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion
  • Initial evaluation of jaundice

The disadvantage of USG is the operator dependence.

HIFU (high intensity focussed USG) is a therapeutic application of USG. It is useful for the treatment of fibroids. HIFU exploits the thermal effects of high-powered tightly-focused ultrasound beams so that very small target tissues can be heated and coagulated.

questions.text: Chest radiography of a patient revealed the following finding. Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows superior rib notching. Coarctation of aorta is associated with inferior rib notching.

Hyperparathyroidism and neurofibromatosis cause both superior and inferior rib notching.

Causes of superior rib notching are:

  • Normal finding in the elderly
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Marfan's syndrome
  • Paraplegics and poliomyelitis

Causes for inferior rib notching (Roesler sign) are:

  • Unilateral:
    • Subclavian artery occlusion.
    • Coarctation of aorta involving left subclavian or anomalous right subclavian artery
  • Bilateral:
    • Coarctation of aorta, occlusion, aortitis
    • Takayasu’s disease and atheroma of subclavian artery
    • Pulmonary oligemia (ToF, pulmonary atresia, stenosis)
    • SVC or IVC obstruction
    • AV malformation
    • Neurofibromatosis type 1

questions.text: A young woman with ongoing seizures and respiratory distress was rushed to the casualty by her relatives with an alleged history of attempted suicide by drug overdose. She was febrile, her heart rate was 180 bpm, BP was 70/50 mmHg. Her mouth was dry and her pupils were dilated. ABG showed a pH of 7.1, bicarbonate level was 14 mmol/L and pCO2 was 30 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning i.e metabolic acidosis, tachycardia, hypotension, and pupillary dilatation. Imipramine is a TCA. 

Tricyclic antidepressant overdose:

Clinical features:

  • CNS- seizures, respiratory depression, drowsiness, delirium. 
  • CVS - sinus tachycardia, hypotension, prolonged PR/QRS/QT interval, arrhythmias (ventricular tachycardia, fibrillation)
  • Anticholinergic - dilated pupils, dry mouth, urinary retention, hyperthermia

Treatment:

  • Oxygen supplementation and IV fluids
  • Activated charcoal if the patient is brought within two hours of ingestion (unless ileus present)
  • IV sodium bicarbonate (attenuates the TCA-induced cardiotoxicity and metabolic acidosis)

Note: Dialysis is not very helpful in the management of TCA overdose.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for erectile dysfunction. Which of the following will help differentiate a psychological cause from an organic one?

choices.text: Decreased vibratory perception in the penis
Absence of erection with any partner

questions.solution:
The presence of nocturnal penile tumescence almost rules out organic causes of erectile dysfunction.

Organic causes are considered negligible in the following:

  • Spontaneous erections at times when he does not plan to have intercourse.
  • Having morning erections or nocturnal penile tumescence (erection during REM sleep).
  • Only sporadic erectile dysfunction.
  • Having good erections with masturbation.
  • Having a good erection with partners other than his usual one.

Organic (non-psychogenic) causes of erectile dysfunction:

  • Vasculogenic - arterial insufficiency, venous leak
  • Endocrinologic - hypogonadism, hyperprolactinemia
  • Neurogenic
  • Iatrogenic

questions.text: A 49-year-old man was brought to the casualty by the local police after they found him lying in a roadside drain. On examination, his speech was slurred and he was unable to recall any of the events that happened in the past 2 hours. His serum alcohol level was 260 mg/dl. "Blackouts" are periods of anterograde memory loss that occur due to alcohol intoxication when the blood level of alcohol is between 200-300 mg/dl. It is due to the inhibition of the action of glutamate on NMDA receptors.

questions.text:
If a person is asked the meaning of "Strike when the rod is hot", and they reply that, "It means that you should strike when the iron rod is hot to melt it because it is the most malleable then".
What aspect of their thinking is demonstrated?
questions.solution:
When the person is asked the meaning of the proverb, they could only answer in the literal sense, and not think what the proverb actually means metaphorically. This is called concrete thinking.

A person capable of abstract thinking would have answered the metaphorical meaning of the proverb given in the question (strike when the iron is hot), which is to take action when the opportunities are favourable.

 Concrete thinking  Abstract thinking
  • Develops first in childhood
  • Understand the literal meaning of a sentence/proverb
  • Focused on facts
  • Cannot compare and contrast different objects/situations
  • Think about a specific event/object individually.
  • Think about a situation in one particular way
  • Can think only about objects they have seen or situations they have experienced
  • Develops later in childhood gradually and emerges in adolescence
  • Understand the deeper meaning of a sentence/ proverb
  • Focused on concepts
  • Can compare and contrast and derive conclusions 
  • Can derive generalizations from a specific event/object.
  • Think about various aspects of a situation simultaneously
  • Can think about objects/situations that were never experienced by them or that do not exist in reality.

questions.text: Which intravenous anesthetic has the maximum incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Etomidate has the highest incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) among intravenous anesthetics.

Propofol has antiemetic properties thereby reducing PONV.

Other potential adverse effects of etomidate:

  • Adrenocortical suppression
  • Myoclonus
  • Seizure precipitation
  • Pain on injection

questions.text: In a patient requiring invasive BP monitoring, which is the preferred artery used for canulation and measurement?
questions.solution:
Radial artery is the preferred artery for invasive blood pressure monitoring because of ease of cannulation, presence of collateral blood flow and less associated complications.

Before cannulating the radial artery, it is essential to perform a modified Allen’s test in order to determine the adequacy of collateral flow to the hand.

The other arteries which can be used for invasive blood pressure monitoring are ulnar, brachial, axillary, and femoral arteries and less commonly dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, and superficial temporal arteries.

questions.text: Soon after the administration of an epidural block with 1.5 % lignocaine with epinephrine, your patient went into bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea soon after the administration of an epidural block suggests accidental subarachnoid (intrathecal) injection resulting in total spinal anaesthesia.

Salient features of total spinal anesthesia:

  • Occurs following attempted epidural/caudal anesthesia if there is accidental intrathecal injection
  • Rapid onset, as the anesthetic required for epidural and caudal anesthesia, is 5–10 times that required for spinal anesthesia
  • High spinal anesthesia extends to involve cranial nerves
  • Accompanied by hypotension, bradycardia, apnea, and loss of consciousness

Prevention:

  • Careful aspiration for CSF (to rule out intrathecal placement) and blood (to rule out intravascular placement) before injecting the local anesthesia
  • Use of a test dose with lidocaine and adrenaline
  • Incremental injection techniques instead of a bolus dose

Treatment:

  • Maintaining an adequate airway and ventilation and supporting the circulation

Other options: 

Option A - Accidental subdural injection manifests after 15-20 minutes with features similar to a high spinal blockade.

Option C - Accidental intravascular injection manifests as systemic toxicity with CNS and CVS symptoms.

Option D - Allergic manifestation presents with hives, angioedema, and bronchospasm.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about lignocaine is false?

choices.text: It blocks active sodium channels with more affinity than resting sodium channels
It can be given orally for cardiac arrhythmias
It's duration of action is increased by adrenaline

questions.solution:
Lignocaine is used for cardiac arrhythmias but is not effective orally because of high first-pass metabolism.

Option A: Local anaesthetics have more affinity for active sodium channels over resting channels.

Option B: Lignocaine use can result in cardiac toxicity especially at higher doses where it interferes with impulse conduction.

Option D: Vasoconstrictor like adrenaline increases the duration of action of lignocaine when used for infiltration anaesthesia.

questions.text: Which is the shortest acting muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Suxamethonium (succinyl choline) is the shortest acting muscle relaxant.

It has a rapid onset (30–60 s) and short duration of action (typically less than 10 min) due to rapid hydrolysis by butyrylcholinesterase (aka plasma cholinesterase or pseudocholinesterase).

Other options:

  • Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. It has an intermediate duration of action, which means it lasts longer than Suxamethonium but shorter than some other muscle relaxants like Pancuronium. Vecuronium is often used in surgical settings to provide muscle relaxation and facilitate intubation and mechanical ventilation.
  • Pancuronium is another non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. It has a longer duration of action compared to Vecuronium, making it a medium-acting muscle relaxant. Pancuronium is used for muscle relaxation during surgery and mechanical ventilation but has a longer-lasting effect compared to Suxamethonium.
  • Pipecuronium is another non-depolarizing muscle relaxant with an intermediate duration of action, similar to Vecuronium. It is used in clinical settings for muscle relaxation during surgery or other procedures that require controlled muscle paralysis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents in December with the following lesion on the extensor aspect of the elbow. The lesions are associated with itching. He consumes alcohol and smokes around 9 cigarettes every day. When the doctor scratched the lesions, the scales initially increased. On successive removal of the scales, there was a glossy red membrane. On removal of the membrane, there were pinpoint bleeding spots. He says that similar lesions are also present on the trunk. All other features mentioned below can be found in this patient except
questions.solution:
The given image shows red scaly plaque with silvery-white fine scales, and the lesion on scratching shows Auspitz's sign on scratching. These features are suggestive of psoriasis in the patient. Pautrier's microabscess is a feature of mycosis fungoides.

Psoriasis is a chronic, inflammatory and proliferative condition of the skin that also involves various organ manifestations. 

Several factors play a role in the development of the disease. They can be streptococcal infections, medications like beta-blockers, non‐steroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and angiotensin‐converting enzymes, alcohol abuse, cigarette smoking, and psychological stress.

Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis and is seen in 80-90% of patients. The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash. The lesions are red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin. They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring. They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

When the lesions are scratched, the scaling increases initially. The successive removal of scales usually reveals an underlying smooth, glossy red membrane. This membrane when removed shows small bleeding points. This finding is called Auspitz’s sign.

The nails may be involved in psoriasis. The nails grow quickly in patients with psoriasis. Involvement of nail matrix disease leads to pits, ridges, and grooves of the nail plate. Involvement of nail bed causes subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, and distal onycholysis.

Histopathology will show the presence of hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, the disappearance of the granular layer, and epidermal hyperplasia. In the Malpighian layer, neutrophils may accumulate to form the characteristic spongiform pustules of Kogoj. Accumulation of neutrophils in the stratum corneum forms Munro microabscess. There is hyperplasia and elongation of rete ridges with dilated and tortuous blood vessels.

choices.text: Eye and skeletal defects are seen

questions.solution:
The image shows cutaneous macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches, corresponding to the lines of Blaschko, suggestive of hypomelanosis of Ito.

It is a rare neuroectodermal disorder of pigmentation. It is associated with epilepsy and mental retardation. Extracutaneous findings include neurological, ophthalmological, and skeletal defects.

questions.text: A young female presented with the following findings on the face. Which among the following will not be useful for its treatment?
questions.solution:
The age of the patient and the presence of papules and pustules with an erythematous base on the face are suggestive of acne. All the above agents are useful in the treatment of acne except topical fluocinolone (topical steroid). Corticosteroids may provoke an acneform reaction irrespective of their route of administration.

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. It is commonly seen in teenagers. It can vary from very mild comedonal acne to severe aggressive pustular acne. These eventually may lead to scarring due to sinus formation.

Acne results from the combination of:

  • Increased sebaceous gland activity under the influence of androgens - oily skin
  • Abnormal follicular differentiation with increased keratinization- hypercornification of the duct due to increased IL-1
  • Microbial hypercolonization of the follicular canal leading to its inflammation.

Management-

  • Mild comedonal acne is treated with a topical retinoid. Mild papular and pustular acne is treated with topical retinoid and topical antibiotics.
  • Moderate papular/pustular acne and moderate nodular acne are treated with oral antibiotic + topical retinoid with or without benzoyl peroxide. 
  • Severe nodular and conglobate acne are treated with oral isotretinoin.

Tazarotene is a fourth‐generation retinoid, which is available for the treatment of acne.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman complains of yellowish discoloration of her axillary sweat and staining of the clothing for 15 days. She has no other complaints. On examination, yellowish concretions are noted on the hair shafts of the left axilla which have formed hard nodular masses. Underlying skin is normal. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of trichomycosis axillaris which is caused by Corynebacterium tenuis.

It is a superficial infection of axillary and pubic hairs with the formation of yellow, black, or red nodular concretions on the hair shaft. The axillary sweat may be yellow, black, or red according to the color of the concretions, and the clothing may be stained.

The condition is usually asymptomatic and the patient is often unaware of its presence. The use of an effective antiperspirant such as aluminum chloride is a rapid means of therapy.

questions.text: A patient presents to the dermatology clinic complaining that a birthmark that was asymptomatic has now become pruritic with the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows an eczematous ring surrounding a melanocytic naevus (birthmark), suggestive of halo dermatitis. 

It is also known as Meyerson nevus. Histology shows a benign naevus surrounded by a dermal lymphocytic and eosinophilic infiltrate, with acanthosis, spongiosis, and parakeratosis.

The condition usually resolves spontaneously within a few months without involution of the nevus.

Other options:

Option A: Chronic superficial scaly dermatitis is a broad term that can encompass various skin conditions, including psoriasis and eczema. Both psoriasis and eczema can cause pruritic (itchy) and scaly skin.

Option B: Nummular dermatitis is a specific type of dermatitis characterized by coin-shaped or round plaques with scaling and itching. It often occurs on the limbs and trunk.

Option C: Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that can present with various symptoms, including changes in the appearance of moles or birthmarks. Patients would have features like irregular borders, color variation, or rapid growth.

questions.text: An 84-year-old man has been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following can be used to assess his cerebral perfusion?
questions.solution:
Tc HMPAO (technetium-99m hexamethyl propylenamine oxime) SPECT is used for the assessment of cerebral perfusion. In Alzheimer's disease, it shows reduced perfusion of the temporoparietal region.

Option B: In-111 (Indium) DTPA is injected intrathecally to assess CSF flow.

Option C: Tc-99m (Technetium) MIBI is used for parathyroid scintigraphy.

Option D: Tl-201 (Thallium) is used in myocardial perfusion scanning.

questions.text: An oncologist orders a bone scan to assess for bony metastases in a 49-year-old woman with breast cancer.  Which of the following radioactive isotope is used?
questions.solution:
Technetium tagged to various substrates is used for bone scans.

The patient is injected with a small amount of radioactive material such as 600 MBq of technetium-99m-MDP and scanned with a gamma camera, a device sensitive to the radiation emitted by the injected material. MDP (methyl diphosphonate) adsorbs into the hydroxyapatite crystals and accumulates in the areas of active bone formation.
